questions.question: What is an exoplanet?
answers: A. A planet outside our solar system
B. A planet inside our solar system
C. A star outside our galaxy
D. A moon in another solar system

questions.question: Which method is most commonly used to detect exoplanets?
What is the habitable zone?
answers: A. A region around a star where water can exist as liquid
B. A region where stars are born
C. The orbit closest to the star
D. The area around a planet where life exists

questions.question: What is the name of the first exoplanet discovered orbiting a Sun-like star?
Which space telescope is known for discovering thousands of exoplanets?
What is the closest known exoplanet to Earth?
Which term describes an exoplanet's ability to support liquid water on its surface?
How are exoplanets like HD 189733 b named?
answers: C. From the catalog and order of discovery
D. Based on the planet's color

questions.question: What are exoplanets primarily composed of?
answers: B. Elements similar to solar system planets with varying compositions
D. Exclusively made of ice and water

questions.question: Which type of exoplanet is often referred to as a 'super-Earth'?
answers: A. A planet larger than Earth but smaller than Neptune
B. A planet similar in size to Mars
C. A gas giant larger than Jupiter
D. A planet that orbits two stars

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the Kepler Space Telescope?
answers: A. It is designed to study the atmosphere of exoplanets.
B. It has discovered thousands of exoplanet candidates.
C. It only detects gas giants.
D. It is located on the surface of Mars.

questions.question: Which of the following missions is focused on characterizing the atmospheres of exoplanets?
What is the term used for a planet that orbits two stars?
What is the primary reason for the interest in studying exoplanets?
answers: B. To discover potential habitats for life
C. To explore new solar systems

questions.question: What is the 'Goldilocks Zone'?
answers: A. The zone where planets have no atmosphere
B. The region around a star where conditions are just right for liquid water
C. The area where gas giants are formed
D. The zone where only rocky planets can exist
